snippet.description:
On January 20, 2021, Democrat leader, Joseph Biden was sworn in as the 46th President of the United States. He took up the mantle of leadership in the midst of a debilitating public health crisis, a badly damaged economy and a deeply divided nation. America's global leadership was also on the decline while tensions were simmering with its closest strategic rival, China.

What are his main priorities and accomplishments during his first 100 days in office? Will his tough stance on China create a new instability in the region? And can President Biden rise up to the challenge in the midst of numerous challenges facing America and the rest of the world?

For greater INSIGHT into issues affecting Asia: 
https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkMf14VQEvTaHr6oTqYbWqKOsmcveuhca

===============
ABOUT THE SHOW: Insight investigates and analyses topical issues that impact Asia and the rest of the world. 
==========================

snippet.description:
India has recorded more than a million Covid-19 cases in just a few days.

The number of reported cases declined slightly on Tuesday, to 323,144 from the peak of 352,991 the day before, bringing the total cases to nearly 17 million with 192,000 deaths.

Deaths have been steadily rising in India as a deadly second wave of Covid infections devastates the country, with 380 recorded in Delhi alone on Monday.

Medical oxygen, intensive care unit (ICU) beds and life-saving medicines are falling short.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
US police officers are seen mocking a 73-year-old dementia sufferer as they watch video of her shoulder going "pop" during her forcible arrest, according to footage released by her lawyer.

Karen Garner was detained on 26 June last year after she walked out of a Walmart in the state of Colorado without paying for $13 of items.

Her elbow was fractured and shoulder dislocated, says her attorney.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
Fighting erupted between the Burmese military and a separatist group in the southeast of Myanmar, close to the border with Thailand.
The ethnic insurgents, the Karen National Union, captured and destroyed an army post as part of their campaign to reduce the military's presence in Karen state, where thousands of people have been displaced by a resurgence of fighting.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
A rare Siberian tiger was on the loose in the village of Linhu in Heilongjiang province, China.

Villagers were told to stay inside and lock their windows and doors as the big cat roamed around.

It was eventually captured and transferred to a big cat reserve.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

snippet.description:
As India‚Äôs coronavirus crisis continues to surge, patients are dying without oxygen as hospitals buckle under the pressure as the crisis continues to intensify.  Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

International efforts are under way to help India as the country suffers critical oxygen shortages amid a devastating surge in Covid cases.

The UK has begun sending ventilators and oxygen concentrator devices. EU members are also due to send aid.

The US is lifting a ban on sending raw materials abroad, enabling India to make more of the AstraZeneca vaccine.

India's capital Delhi has extended its lockdown as overcrowded hospitals continue to turn patients away.

The government has approved plans for more than 500 oxygen generation plants across the country to boost supplies.

Meanwhile neighbouring Bangladesh has announced that it will close its border with India from Monday to prevent the spread of the virus.

The BBC‚Äôs Aleem Maqbool reports.

#Coronavirus #BBCNews #Newsnight

Newsnight is the BBC's flagship news and current affairs TV programme - with analysis, debate, exclusives, and robust interviews.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/BBCNewsnight

snippet.description:
The British-Iranian aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been sentenced to a further 12 months in prison in Tehran, on charges of spreading propaganda against the Iranian regime. 

In March 2021 she completed a 5-year sentence for spying - a charge she strongly denied. 

Her husband has said he is bitterly disappointed at the court's latest decision. 

Huw Edwards presents BBC News at Ten reporting by Caroline Hawley.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
There are warnings that India is running out of coronavirus vaccines, despite its government promising to rapidly accelerate the national vaccination programme. 

Less than 10% of India's population has so far received a first vaccination and Indian manufacturers have complained of shortages of vital raw materials as they try to meet the huge demand.

India‚Äôs healthcare system is struggling to deal with the scale of the nation‚Äôs  Covid crisis.  More than 352,000 new cases have been reported in the past 24 hours.

snippet.description:
The Indonesian navy has released a poignant video showing the crew of a sunken submarine singing on board their vessel.

The video, filmed a few weeks ago, shows the sailors singing an Indonesian hit called Sampai Jumpa (see you later).

Officials confirmed on Sunday that the KRI Nanggala - which sank off the coast of Bali on Wednesday - had been found split into three pieces on the sea bed.

All 53 crew were confirmed as dead.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

snippet.description:
The European Commission said it's suing the coronavirus vaccine manufacturer AstraZeneca for not respecting its vaccine supply contract, and for not having a "reliable" plan to ensure timely deliveries.

AstraZeneca said the move was "without merit" and that it would "strongly defend itself in court".

The legal action marks an escalation in a long-running dispute between the two sides over the supply of coronavirus vaccines.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

snippet.description:
India is suffering critical shortages of medical equipment and oxygen amid a devastating surge in Covid-19 cases. 

 With the death toll steadily increasing, families are being forced to find their own oxygen and to wait to cremate their loved ones.  Many have turned to the black market, where prices of essential medicines, oxygen cylinders and concentrators have skyrocketed. 

 Most hospitals in the capital Delhi are full and many of them are refusing new admissions due to the uncertainty over oxygen supply.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews

Documental sobre Bitcoin y Criptomonedas (Orig.: "Bitcoin - Beyond The Bubble"): ¬øQu√© es Bitcoin? Con la llegada de Bitcoin, la principal moneda digital del mundo, por primera vez en la historia el dinero ya no est√° controlado por los bancos o los gobiernos, sino por las personas que lo utilizan. Pero, ¬øde d√≥nde viene esta moneda? ¬øC√≥mo funciona? ¬øY es realmente el camino a seguir, o s√≥lo un destello en la sart√©n?

Si el concepto de bitcoin le intriga, pero se siente intimidado por la complicada jerga tecnol√≥gica que lo rodea, el documental "Bitcoin: m√°s all√° de la burbuja" es para usted. Esta incisiva visi√≥n de conjunto explica los entresijos de la criptodivisa de una manera absorbente y f√°cilmente digerible. 
La pel√≠cula comienza con un examen de las monedas populares a lo largo de la historia, incluyendo nuestra larga dependencia de los metales preciosos como el oro y la plata, as√≠ como el sistema del d√≥lar estadounidense que se emplea m√°s com√∫nmente en la actualidad. El Bitcoin es visto por muchos como la siguiente evoluci√≥n l√≥gica de estas monedas, y una muy deseable. Bitcoin, junto con una interfaz conocida como blockchain, es una red completamente descentralizada que elimina todos los intermediarios del proceso de intercambio de divisas. Este es uno de los principales factores que lo diferencian de las transacciones con los bancos tradicionales o las compa√±√≠as de tarjetas de cr√©dito, y es una raz√≥n importante por la que estas instituciones firmemente establecidas se ven amenazadas por la creciente popularidad de la criptodivisa. La red es especialmente √∫til para quienes no son miembros activos del sistema bancario, pero sus beneficios trascienden las necesidades del individuo. Como se detalla en la pel√≠cula, los pa√≠ses inseguros en cuanto a la moneda utilizan el bitcoin para evitar lidiar con gobiernos corruptos y sistemas bancarios centrales infestados de codicia. Muchas de las regiones m√°s ricas del mundo dudan a la hora de realizar transacciones financieras con pa√≠ses del tercer mundo debido al fraude desenfrenado de las tarjetas de cr√©dito. Bitcoin elimina este riesgo y, por tanto, abre un nuevo campo de revitalizaci√≥n para estas naciones empobrecidas. Incre√≠blemente, tambi√©n puede utilizarse para mejorar las normas de privacidad, proteger la integridad de las elecciones nacionales y ayudar a las familias que luchan en todo el mundo a conseguir derechos de propiedad. La pel√≠cula se sumerge de lleno en la respuesta a los cr√≠ticos m√°s ac√©rrimos del bitcoin, incluso en cuestiones relacionadas con la resistencia de la tecnolog√≠a si llegara a crecer mucho m√°s all√° de las expectativas en un futuro pr√≥ximo, y las seguridades que existen para evitar el fraude generalizado. Con testimonios perspicaces de destacados l√≠deres y pronosticadores de la escena financiera mundial, "Bitcoin: m√°s all√° de la burbuja" dibuja un futuro optimista en el que todo el mundo puede ser due√±o de su propio dinero.

Bitcoin - M√°s all√° de la burbuja (2018)

Director: Tim Delmastro
Escritores: Tim Delmastro
Estrellas: Jeff Berwick, Catherine Austin Fitts, Trace Mayer

Kenetic: Handshake Could Become Bigger Than Bitcoin in 5 Years. Kenetic Founder & Managing Partner Jehan Chu, an investor in cryptocurrency since 2013 sees bitcoin hitting $100,000 in 3Q. But he sees Handshake becoming bigger than bitcoin in the next 5 years. He speaks with Paul Allen and Shery Ahn on "Bloomberg Daybreak: Asia". (Source: Bloomberg)

Filmed in 21 countries, the panoramic story of the coronavirus pandemic‚Äôs first year as seen through the eyes of people all across the world. Part one of a two-part series.

Subscribe on YouTube: http://bit.ly/1BycsJW 

Drawing on extensive personal and local footage, ‚ÄúThe Virus That Shook the World‚Äù tells the story of people across the globe who have experienced the pandemic and its consequences in different ways ‚Äî from a food blogger in Wuhan, China; to a filmmaker in a remote Indigenous village in Brazil; to a musician and puppeteer in Delhi, India.

From series director James Bluemel and series producer Alice Henley, the two-part special shows how the impacts of the disease that has now killed more than 3 million people have overlapped and differed across cultures, races, faiths and privilege; how various governments have responded; and how the pandemic has exposed existing inequities and social problems.

#Documentaries #CoronavirusPandemic #DocumentarySpecial

snippet.description:
In this excerpt from "The Virus That Shook the World," Khadija Abdulahi Hussein and Hussein Moyo describe the events surrounding their 13-year-old son, Yasin Hussein Moyo, being killed by police.

Subscribe on YouTube: http://bit.ly/1BycsJW 

Not every death linked to the COVID-19 pandemic has come from the disease itself. Khadija Abdulahi Hussein and Hussein Moyo share the story of their son, who was fatally shot by police enforcing a COVID curfew in Nairobi, Kenya.

Drawing on extensive personal and local footage, "The Virus That Shook the World" tells the story of the Moyo family and of other people across the globe who have experienced the pandemic and its consequences in different ways ‚Äî from a food blogger in Wuhan, China; to a filmmaker in a remote Indigenous village in Brazil; to a musician and puppeteer in Delhi, India.

The two-part special shows how the impacts of the disease that has now killed more than 3 million people have overlapped and differed across cultures, races, faiths and privilege; how various governments have responded; and how the pandemic has exposed existing inequities and social problems.

Watch "The Virus That Shook the World" in full, from series director James Bluemel and series producer Alice Henley, beginning April 26 and 27: https://to.pbs.org/31YcLl6

snippet.description:
When Khadija Abdulahi Hussein thinks about her son Yasin, she remembers him dancing, laughing, helping others ‚Äî and wanting the entire world to know who he was.

‚ÄúBut I didn't know it would be like this,‚Äù she says in the above excerpt from the new FRONTLINE documentary "The Virus That Shook the World," her voice breaking. ‚ÄúI wanted them to know him as a grown man. I mean as a grown-up, with a family, and not dead.‚Äù

Subscribe on YouTube: http://bit.ly/1BycsJW 

In this excerpt from "The Virus That Shook the World," Khadija Abdulahi Hussein and Hussein Moyo share video and memories of their son, Yasin Hussein Moyo, fatally shot at age 13 on the family‚Äôs balcony by police enforcing a COVID curfew in Nairobi, Kenya.

‚ÄúNow it's like the gift I was given, someone came and took it away,‚Äù Khadija says of her son.

Drawing on extensive personal and local footage, The Virus That Shook the World tells the story of the Moyo family and of other people across the globe who have experienced the pandemic and its consequences in different ways ‚Äî from a food blogger in Wuhan, China; to a filmmaker in a remote Indigenous village in Brazil; to a musician and puppeteer in Delhi, India.

The two-part special shows how the impacts of the disease that has now killed more than 3 million people have overlapped and differed across cultures, races, faiths and privilege; how various governments have responded; and how the pandemic has exposed existing inequities and social problems.

Watch "The Virus That Shook the World" in full, from series director James Bluemel and series producer Alice Henley, beginning April 26 and 27: https://to.pbs.org/31YcLl6

snippet.description:
The Aircraft Carrier USS America (LHA 6) Conduct Flight Deck Operations.

USS America (LHA-6), is an amphibious assault ship of the United States Navy and the lead ship of her class. The fourth U.S. warship to be named for the United States of America, she was delivered in spring of 2014, replacing Peleliu of the Tarawa class. Her mission is to act as the flagship of an expeditionary strike group or amphibious ready group, carrying part of a Marine expeditionary unit into battle and putting them ashore with helicopters and V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft, supported by F-35B Lightning II aircraft and helicopter gunships.

In South Korea, there has been a growth in illegal ‚Äúghost doctors‚Äù in the country‚Äôs thriving plastic surgery industry. ‚ÄúGhost doctors‚Äù are stand-in medical workers who perform the procedure instead of the hired surgeon. It‚Äôs done to increase the number of surgeries conducted, maximising profits. One victim of the practice is Kwon Dae-hee, who died of severe bleeding after undergoing jawline surgery in 2016. CCTV footage showed the 26-year-old was left unattended during surgery. The victim‚Äôs family was reportedly compensated 430 million won (US$386,900) in 2019, while the surgeons involved face manslaughter charges.

On April 27, 2021, India had reported over 300,000 daily cases for six consecutive days, with more than 2,700 deaths recorded on the same day.

Thakhin Kai Bwor has been publishing the Myanmar Gazette ‚Äì the only Burmese-language newspaper in the US ‚Äì for nearly 15 years. The 54-year-old edits and lays out the paper, and hand-delivers it to California neighbourhoods with a large Burmese-American presence. The paper, and its popular online edition, target around 300,000 Burmese speakers living in the US, and are offered for free, with advertising support from mostly Burmese-owned businesses. Its coverage is highly critical of Myanmar‚Äôs military coup in February, informed by Bwor‚Äôs own experience taking part in anti-government protests in 1988.

Hundreds of community pantries have been set up around the Philippines to help residents cope with strict coronavirus lockdown restrictions. Local people have been sharing food and essential supplies as the nation imposes the measures to fight a surge in new infections. The surge has left many of the nation‚Äôs hospitals on the verge of collapse as the number of cases logged since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic topped 1 million on April 26, 2021. The Philippines has the second-highest caseload in Southeast Asia after Indonesia.

Hong Kong and Singapore will launch their long-delayed travel bubble, with each city allowing quarantine-free entry from the other Asian air hub from May 26, 2021. Announcing the arrangements on April 26, officials from both sides said they believe sufficient progress has been made in containing Covid-19 outbreaks to make it safe for residents to travel without isolating upon arrival. Plans to start the travel bubble in November 2020 were put on hold by a case surge in Hong Kong.

As Minari star Youn Yuh-jung won the Oscar for best supporting actress on April 25, 2021, the film also brought pride to minari farmers in South Korea. Minari is a leafy green that takes at least a year to grow; it serves as a metaphor for the immigrant experience in the 2020 film about a Korean-American family who started a farm in Arkansas.

Hundreds of items such as the original prototype for the 'Alien' film character 'Big Chap' and the 'Edward Scissorhands' props, worn by actor Johnny Deep, were on display, in Beverly Hills on Monday,¬†two days before they are set to go under the hammer. 

The auction block named 'Hollywood Legends' includes several legendary items from the film Mecca; from actor Bill Murray's Air Jordans from film 'Space Jam' to actor Al Pacino's 'Tony Montana' suit from 'Scarface', a wand from the 'Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire' film and a bowling alley ball return from the 'The Big Lebowski' film.

Talking about the most important piece in the auction block,¬†the original prototype for the 'Alien' film character 'Big Chap',¬†Julien's Auctions Director of Gallery Operations Kody Frederick, assured that the "[artist] H.R. Giger had originally viewed him ['Big Chap'] to be translucent." 

"It has not been seen for 40 years and it is here in our auction. We expect it to go anywhere from 40,000 to 60,000 dollars," Frederick added.

A second auction block called "Hollywood Legends & Luminaries Auction" includes actress Marilyn Monroe's personally owned lip brush and actress Greta Garbo's cigarette holder. The auction blocks include over 800 items and are expected to fetch between $1 and 2 million (‚Ç¨0.8 and 1.7 million) in total. 

The auctions¬†are¬†set to take place on April 28 and 29 at¬†Julien's Auction.

UFC Heavyweight Champion Francis Ngannou made a triumphant return to Douala on Monday to show his champion's belt to his fans.

The Mixed Martial Arts fighter was greeted by crowds in the Cameroon city before attending a ceremony with the local governor.

"I wanted once again to thank you, all of you and all the Cameroon people," Ngannou said during the ceremony.

A former migrant and homeless in Paris, Ngannou got to the top of the UFC roster with impressive knockout victories. 

He defeated former UFC heavyweight champion Stipe Miocic last month in Las Vegas to become the third African-born UFC champion.

----

SOT, Fan (French): "It was an honour for me to have seen the World Champion pass next to us. It is a shame he could not stop so that we could see him for two minutes. I needed to see him for at least two minutes but the crowd was massive so he could not stop but I was still able to saw his face live."

SOT, Francis Ngannou, UFC Heavyweight champion (French): "I wanted once again to thank you, all of you and all the Cameroon people."

SOT, Francis Ngannou, UFC Heavyweight champion (French): "I think we are all invincible because we carry an untamable and formidable force."

SOT, Samuel Dieudonne Ivaha Diboua, Local Governor (French): "It was time, after going overseas to the battle field, that he came back with the most prestigious trophy in his discipline. It was time for the city of Douala, which has followed his ascension, to be here after this result and to be here for this shining star."

#Cameroon #Douala #UFC #FrancisNgannou

A train carrying around 70 tonnes of oxygen in tankers arrived in New Delhi early on Tuesday as India continues to battle severe hospital oxygen shortages.

The train was seen rolling into Delhi Cantonment Station before the tankers were dispatched by road to several hospitals in the area.

India broke the world record for the highest daily tally of new coronavirus infections last week, with the country struggling to provide medical assistance to patients, amid a lack of ventilators and hospital beds.

India has seen over 17.60 million confirmed cases of coronavirus and 197,890 related deaths since the start of the pandemic as of Tuesday, according to Johns Hopkins University.

snippet.description:
MEPs are meeting to discuss and vote on giving the European Parliament's consent to the European Council's decision in concluding the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement in Brussels on Tuesday, April 27.

The agreement, which has been provisionally applied since January 1, 2021, once approved, will govern the new post-Brexit relationship between the EU and the UK.

The deal establishes trade on zero-tariff/quota terms and covers a wide range of areas, including energy, transport, and fisheries, although extensive non-tariff barriers exist."

snippet.description:
Ruptly is live from Sikh Gurudwara temple in Ghaziabad on Tuesday, April 27, as people queue to receive oxygen. Shri Guru Singh Sabha Gurudwara together with Khalsa Help International NGO organised free oxygen supplies for patients who were declined at state hospitals, due to shortages.

Hospitals have been struggling to provide oxygen to their COVID patients, with the Indian Supreme Court ordering Prime Minister Narendra Modi to come up with an oxygen distribution plan.

India broke the world record for the highest daily tally of new coronavirus infections last week, with the country struggling to provide medical assistance to patients, amid a lack of ventilators and hospital beds.

India has seen over 17,6 million confirmed cases of coronavirus and 197,890 related deaths since the start of the pandemic as of Tuesday, according to Johns Hopkins University.

snippet.description:
On the 35th Anniversary of the event!  A 1991 American Made of TV docu-drama starring Jon Voight, Jason Robards, and Sammi Davis. The film plot chronicles the True story about the tragic nuclear power plant accident in Chernobyl and interweaves the stories of a fireman at the nuclear power plant, his pregnant wife, the government officials whose policies helped and hindered rescue efforts and America's Dr. Robert Gale (Jon Voight), who led the international medical team that helped treat survivors of the disaster.

The film premiered on TNT on April¬†22,¬†1991 and was filmed on location in the USSR (Moscow and Kursk).

On the night of April 26, 1986, the Chernobyl disaster leads to the horrific death of a number of people and rocks the lives of everyone living near the ill-fated soviet nuclear plant. However, the secretive communist USSR government refuses to let anyone know how serious the catastrophe is, and orders an immediate evacuation of everyone living in the vicinity of the plant including the local farmers, some of whom refuse to leave, and the town of Pripyat, where the people who work in the plant live with their families. Yelena Mashenko, the wife of one of the firemen dangerously irradiated at the plant while attempting to put out the fire that broke out after the explosion tries to find her hospitalized husband in the chaos. Meanwhile, in California, a rich but dedicated real life American physician, Dr. Robert Gale, learns about the Chernobyl disaster, and travels to Moscow to offer his help, being an expert on the latest groundbreaking methods for treating bone marrow-related cancer.

On the 35th Anniversary of the event!  A 1991 American Made of TV docu-drama starring Jon Voight, Jason Robards, and Sammi Davis. The film plot chronicles the True story about the tragic nuclear power plant accident in Chernobyl and interweaves the stories of a fireman at the nuclear power plant, his pregnant wife, the government officials whose policies helped and hindered rescue efforts and America's Dr. Robert Gale (Jon Voight), who led the international medical team that helped treat survivors of the disaster.

The film premiered on TNT on April¬†22,¬†1991 and was filmed on location in the USSR (Moscow and Kursk).

On the night of April 26, 1986, the Chernobyl disaster leads to the horrific death of a number of people and rocks the lives of everyone living near the ill-fated soviet nuclear plant. However, the secretive communist USSR government refuses to let anyone know how serious the catastrophe is, and orders an immediate evacuation of everyone living in the vicinity of the plant including the local farmers, some of whom refuse to leave, and the town of Pripyat, where the people who work in the plant live with their families. Yelena Mashenko, the wife of one of the firemen dangerously irradiated at the plant while attempting to put out the fire that broke out after the explosion tries to find her hospitalized husband in the chaos. Meanwhile, in California, a rich but dedicated real life American physician, Dr. Robert Gale, learns about the Chernobyl disaster, and travels to Moscow to offer his help, being an expert on the latest groundbreaking methods for treating bone marrow-related cancer.

---------------
Under the leadership of the President and Secretary of State, the U.S. Department of State leads America‚Äôs foreign policy through diplomacy, advocacy, and assistance by advancing the interests of the American people, their safety and economic prosperity. On behalf of the American people we promote and demonstrate democratic values and advance a free, peaceful, and prosperous world.

The Secretary of State, appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, is the President's chief foreign affairs adviser. The Secretary carries out the President's foreign policies through the State Department, which includes the Foreign Service, Civil Service and U.S. Agency for International Development.

snippet.description:
Turkey's Directorate of Communications has organised an exhibition to honor the victims of Armenian terrorism. Between the 1970s and 1990s, an organisation called the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia carried out dozens of terror attacks across the world. The group targeted Turkish diplomats and civilians in an attempt to force Turkey to acknowledge the so called 'genocide'. Our correspondent Muttalip Erdogan has more from Los Angeles.
#TurkishDiplomats

snippet.description:
In the US, there's a state of emergency in Elizabeth City, North Carolina - six days after sheriff's deputies shot and killed Andrew Brown Jr while serving an arrest warrant. After demanding to see police video from the shooting - on Monday Brown's family was allowed to see what their attorneys call a 'snippet' of what happened when he was killed - just 20 seconds of the incident. His son saying, what he saw was an "execution" by police. NBC's Jay Gray has the details.
#AndrewBrownBodycam

snippet.description:
Commemorations have been held in Ukraine to mark the 35th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. One of four reactors blew up during a botched safety test, killing at least 28 people in the immediate aftermath, many of them firefighters sent to extinguish the burning reactor. Thousands have subsequently died from the effects of radiation, and the area is still sealed off. Simon McGregor-Wood has the reactor.
#ChernobylExplosion

Natasha Hussain reports.

snippet.description:
Smoke billows from dozens of pyres lit inside a parking lot that has been turned into a makeshift crematorium, after India‚Äôs capital was gripped by a deadly wave of the pandemic that has deluged its hospitals and crematoriums equally. Loved ones filled with grief for their lost family members watch and perform rites as the pyres burn. "People are just dying, dying and dying... with increasing speed and there is no sign of relief," says Jitender Singh Shanty, the coordinator of the crematorium, who says he has now seen cremations numbering over 100 per day for two days in a row.

"People are just dying, dying and dying... with increasing speed and there is no sign of relief," says Jitender Singh Shanty, the coordinator of the crematorium, who says he has now seen cremations numbering over 100 per day for two days in a row.

snippet.description:
A San Francisco paper store is displaying thousands of origami hearts with positive messages, to show support for the Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) community in the city after a wave of anti-Asian attacks. Linda Mihara, an origami artist and owner of the paper store "Paper Tree", says she has received over 4,000 origami hearts, which she displays in her store's window. "I wanted to do something that would counter the hate," she says. "And so, the best way to counter the hate is with love."

snippet.description:
The Bell UH-1Y Venom (also called Super Huey) is a twin-engine, medium-sized utility helicopter, built by Bell Helicopter under the H-1 upgrade program of the United States Marine Corps. One of the latest members of the numerous Huey family, the UH-1Y is also called "Yankee", based on the NATO phonetic alphabet pronunciation of its variant letter.

The UH-1Y variant modernizes the UH-1 design. The Y-model upgrades pilot avionics to a glass cockpit, adds further safety modifications, and provides the UH-1 with a modern forward-looking infrared system.

Ÿàÿ¥ÿØÿØÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ∏ŸÖÿ© ÿ£ŸÜ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿßŸÑÿ≥ŸÑÿ∑ÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑÿ•ÿ≥ÿ±ÿßÿ¶ŸäŸÑŸäÿ© ÿ•ŸÜŸáÿßÿ° ÿ¨ŸÖŸäÿπ ÿ£ÿ¥ŸÉÿßŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸÇŸÖÿπ ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÖŸäŸäÿ≤ ÿßŸÑÿ™Ÿä ÿ™ŸÖŸÜÿ≠ ÿßŸÖÿ™Ÿäÿßÿ≤ÿß ŸÑŸÑŸäŸáŸàÿØ ÿßŸÑÿ•ÿ≥ÿ±ÿßÿ¶ŸäŸÑŸäŸäŸÜ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ≠ÿ≥ÿßÿ® ÿßŸÑŸÅŸÑÿ≥ÿ∑ŸäŸÜŸäŸäŸÜÿå ÿ®ŸÖÿß ŸÅŸä ÿ∞ŸÑŸÉ ÿ≠ÿ±Ÿäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÜŸÇŸÑÿå Ÿàÿ™ÿÆÿµŸäÿµ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ±ÿßÿ∂Ÿäÿå ŸàŸÖŸÜÿ≠ ÿ™ÿµÿßÿ±Ÿäÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ŸÜÿßÿ°.Ÿàÿ≠ÿ´ ÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÇÿ±Ÿäÿ±Ÿè ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ≠ŸÉŸÖÿ©Ÿé ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÜÿßÿ¶Ÿäÿ© ÿßŸÑÿØŸàŸÑŸäÿ©ÿå ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ≠ŸÇŸäŸÇ ŸÖÿπ ÿßŸÑÿ∂ÿßŸÑÿπŸäŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸàÿ´ŸéŸÇŸäŸÜ ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑÿ¨ÿ±ŸäŸÖÿ™ŸéŸäŸÜ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿ™ŸÖÿ´ŸÑÿ™ŸäŸÜ ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑŸÅÿµŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿπŸÜÿµÿ±Ÿä ŸàÿßŸÑÿßÿ∂ÿ∑ŸáÿßÿØ ŸàŸÖŸÇÿßÿ∂ÿßÿ™ŸáŸÖ. ÿØÿπÿ™ ÿ≠ÿ±ŸÉÿ© ÿßŸÑŸÜŸáÿ∂ÿ© ŸÉŸÑÿß ŸÖŸÜ ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿØŸàŸÑÿ© Ÿàÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿ≠ŸÉŸàŸÖÿ© ŸÑÿßÿ™ÿÆÿßÿ∞ ÿßŸÑÿÆÿ∑Ÿàÿßÿ™ ÿßŸÑŸÖŸÜÿßÿ≥ÿ®ÿ© ŸÑÿ•ŸÜŸáÿßÿ° ÿ£ÿ≤ŸÖÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿπÿØŸäŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸàÿ≤ÿßÿ±Ÿäÿõ Ÿàÿ¨ÿßÿ° ŸÅŸä ÿ®ŸäÿßŸÜ ŸÖÿ¨ŸÑÿ≥ ÿ¥Ÿàÿ±Ÿâ ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿ±ŸÉÿ© ÿ±ŸÅÿ∂Ÿáÿß ŸÖÿß ŸàÿµŸÅÿ™Ÿá ÿ®ÿπŸàÿØÿ© ÿ≠ŸÉŸÖ ÿßŸÑŸÅÿ±ÿØ.
ÿ£ŸÉŸëÿØ ÿ±ÿ¶Ÿäÿ≥ ÿßŸÑÿ≠ŸÉŸàŸÖÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ™ŸàŸÜÿ≥Ÿäÿ© Ÿáÿ¥ÿßŸÖ ŸÖÿ¥Ÿäÿ¥Ÿä ÿπÿØŸÖ ŸÜŸäÿ™Ÿá ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿÆŸÑŸëŸä ÿπŸÜ ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿπÿØŸäŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸàÿ≤ÿßÿ±Ÿä ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿÆŸäÿ± ÿ®ŸÖÿß ÿ£ŸÜŸë ÿßŸÑŸàÿ≤ÿ±ÿßÿ° ŸÜÿßŸÑŸàÿß ÿ´ŸÇÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ±ŸÑŸÖÿßŸÜÿå ŸÖÿ¥ÿØÿØÿßŸã ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ£ŸÜŸëŸáŸÖ ŸÅŸä ÿßŸÑŸÜŸáÿßŸäÿ© ÿ≥Ÿäÿ™ŸàŸÑŸëŸàŸÜ ŸÖŸáÿßŸÖŸáŸÖÿå ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿ≠ÿØ ŸÇŸàŸÑŸá.

snippet.description:
The launch was carried out from the underground silo at the Yasny training ground in the Orenburg region. Voevoda intercontinental ballistic missile is one of the most powerful missiles in the world. The missile was launched to confirm its flight performance. This is necessary to extend the life of the complex for another year. The missile training units successfully hit mock targets at the Kamchatka training ground. The missile was launched as part of a surprise combat readiness inspection of the nuclear deterrent forces.

snippet.description:
President¬†Joe Biden¬†will require federal contractors to pay workers at least $15 an hour in an executive order designed to leverage government purchasing power to boost working conditions for lower-earners employed via taxpayer funds.



Updating an Obama-era measure, Biden‚Äôs order mandates that all federal agencies incorporate what amounts to a $4.05 minimum wage hike into new contract solicitations by January 2022 and into new contracts by March 2022, the White House announced Tuesday. The minimum hourly rate will then rise annually to keep up with inflation.


‚ÄúIt will improve the economic security of families and make progress toward reversing decades of income inequality,‚Äù the White House said in a fact sheet.


The order will likely face opposition in the business community, which has argued that forcing companies to pay at least $15 will stifle job growth in an economy still recovering from the pandemic. Large corporations that do business with the government also have resisted procurement executive orders with labor mandates in the past by taking the administration to court.


The executive order fulfills the president‚Äôs first-week commitment to mandate by his 100th day in office a $15 federal contractor minimum wage, which the White House estimates will apply to ‚Äúhundreds of thousands‚Äù of workers. That would amount to a marginal gain relative to the¬†administration‚Äôs failed bid¬†to more than double the economy-wide hourly minimum to $15 as part of a pandemic stimulus package enacted in March.


Tuesday‚Äôs wage requirements also mark the first in what the Biden administration has vowed will be multiple presidential actions that¬†use executive authority to improve workplace conditions¬†in policy areas that face steep hurdles in Congress. That includes¬†commitments to steer contracts¬†to firms that provide quality benefits and don‚Äôt thwart union organizing drives.


The U.S. Labor Department and the White House Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council will now implement Biden‚Äôs directive in new regulations.


Many businesses that regularly receive contracts from federal agencies, such as construction companies, already pay more than $15 an hour. But the minimum wage increase would more likely affect employees performing other services for agencies, such as cleaning and cooking at federal buildings or staffing call centers to support government initiatives.


The $15 minimum wage will apply not just to agencies that are awarding new and renewed contracts, but also will be applied to existing contracts when those companies undergo an annual review process with the agency, said a senior administration official on a call with reporters.


Biden‚Äôs action gradually eliminates over three years the lower minimum wage of $7.65 for federal contractor employees who rely on tips. By 2024, workers regularly earning gratuities will be subject to the same $15 floor pay as other contractor employees, the order will state. It will also ensure government contractors pay workers with disabilities at least $15 per hour.

snippet.description:
Toyota is building an entire city to tailor-made for self-driving cars. The new ‚ÄòWoven City‚Äô near Japan‚Äôs Mount Fuji envisions a fully autonomous future. 

In late February, Toyota Motor Corp. President Akio Toyoda gathered with a handful of Shinto priests in a white tent at the foot of Mount Fuji. The group prayed ‚Äî as is customary when embarking on new builds in Japan ‚Äî for the smooth completion of a new city to be designed and built by the world‚Äôs largest automaker.

At the site of a recently shuttered factory, Toyoda commented on the significance of replacing a plant that‚Äôs churned out cars since the ‚Äò60s with a 175-acre community to test future technologies such as autonomous vehicles. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a new chapter in our story and in our industry,‚Äù Toyoda, grandson of the carmaker‚Äôs founder, said in an online video commemorating the groundbreaking.


By 2040, a fleet of more than 30 million self-driving vehicles are estimated to be driving on roads globally. Yet today, even the most advanced autonomous features are limited and require driver supervision. Executives and industry experts say the missing link is cities, which need to be wired to funnel massive amounts of data to cars in order for them to meaningfully drive themselves.

Toyota Woven City
An impression of Toyota's Woven City.Source: Toyota Motor Corp.
That‚Äôs why Toyota is building its sensor-laden ‚ÄúWoven City‚Äù from the ground up a two-hour drive outside of Tokyo. There, Toyota will test autonomous vehicles for transport, deliveries and mobile shops alongside the city‚Äôs hand-picked residents as a kind of living laboratory. When construction is completed in 2024, it will seek to offer a model of what urban centers around the world could look like in the age of autonomous transport. Doing so, of course, will require convincing a broader population.

Right now, limited automated driving is achieved by having sensors onboard cars draw information from their environment. Feeding such information back to vehicles will be ‚Äúthe next big leap forward,‚Äù says Hiroki Kuriyama, senior vice president of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. Japan‚Äôs top telecommunications company is partnering with Toyota to develop the technology needed for autonomous car-supporting smart hubs.

The idea, Kuriyama says, is to use sensors and cameras scattered throughout roads, traffic lights and buildings ‚Äî and perhaps even data from mobile phones ‚Äî to gather information on everything from pedestrian traffic to precipitation. That massive data stream will then be processed via optical networks, data centers and the cloud to create a digital ‚Äútwin,‚Äù or mirror image, of the living city. The virtual, synthesized data can then be fed to cars, letting them safely navigate through the real world without human intervention, according to Kuriyama.

The name Woven City is a nod to Toyota‚Äôs origins as a manufacturer of automatic looms, and refers to the stitching together of software, services, vehicles and streets. All that will guide the company‚Äôs autonomous ‚ÄúE-palettes‚Äù ‚Äî transparent shipping container-like vehicles that can accommodate as many as 20 passengers with seats that fold up so that the interior can be re-purposed. E-palettes will run through the city using autonomous vehicle lanes, providing shared transportation, delivering packages and acting as mobile storefronts.

Beyond futuristic mobility options, the city will also feature smart homes that take out trash and restock refrigerators automatically, according to Toyota. The entire ecosystem will also be powered by hydrogen. It‚Äôs a big and ambitious bet for the automaker ‚Äî although no investment figures have been disclosed, costs are likely to run upwards of a billion dollars. To help fund the project, Toyota said last month it would sell as much as 500 billion yen ($4.6 billion) in ‚ÄúWoven Planet Bonds,‚Äù the biggest such issue at the time to be used in part for the new city.

To watch complete coverage on Bloomberg Quicktake 24/7, visit http://www.bloomberg.com/qt/live, or watch on Apple TV, Roku, Samsung Smart TV, Fire TV and Android TV on the Bloomberg app.

snippet.description:
"That's how we try to be proactive and try to get ahead of the game." 

Singapore has topped Bloomberg‚Äôs Covid Resilience Ranking this month, dethroning New Zealand for the first time in our measure of the best and worst places to be in the pandemic era.

The tiny city-state has gotten locally-transmitted cases down to near zero thanks to border curbs and a strict quarantine program, allowing citizens to largely go about their everyday lives, even¬†attending concerts¬†and¬†going on cruises. 

Singapore has already administered vaccines equivalent to cover a fifth of its population, an aspect of pandemic control that other virus eliminators like New Zealand, Australia and Taiwan are¬†lagging on.

At the same time, a quarantine-free air travel bubble between Hong Kong and Singapore is finally slated to get off the ground with a start date of May 26, following setbacks that led to the plan initially being shelved last November.

snippet.description:
Hong Kong leader responds to questions about whether the city‚Äôs annual June 4 vigil marking China‚Äôs 1989 Tiananmen crackdown breaches the national security law.

‚ÄúIt much depends on what is going to happen in those gatherings and whether they will fall into the offences expressly prohibited in the national security law," said Lam.

Last year, thousands gathered across Hong Kong to commemorate victims of China‚Äôs military crackdown in Tiananmen Square, defying an unprecedented ban on congregating for the 2020 vigil.

Hong Kong‚Äôs Beijing-backed administration said the rally couldn‚Äôt go forward because of a ban on gatherings of more than eight people, citing the Covid-19 pandemic. But activists, opposition politicians and critics called it a deliberate attempt to stifle free speech, pointing out that the virus was at that time mostly under control in the city and that larger groups regularly gather in public without any issues from the authorities.

For the past 30+ years, residents of the semi-autonomous city had held a candlelight vigil that draws tens of thousands of attendees for an annual memorial to those who lost their lives when China‚Äôs leadership ordered troops to fire on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing‚Äôs central square and the nearby streets. Estimates of the dead have ranged from hundreds to thousands: there‚Äôs never been an independent investigation.

snippet.description:
India‚Äôs mounting crisis surrounding a surge in coronavirus infections is prompting wealthy families to flee the country by private jet.

With reports of hospital bed, oxygen and drug shortages sweeping social media, Indian tycoons and others able to afford fares running into millions of rupees are booking flights to boltholes in Europe, the Middle East and the Indian Ocean.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not only the ultra rich,‚Äù said Rajan Mehra, chief executive officer at New Delhi-based private jet firm Club One Air. ‚ÄúWhoever can afford to take a private jet are taking private jets.‚Äù

snippet.description:
City leaders say they support the sweeping Department of Justice probe announced Monday into policing in Louisville, Kentucky over the March 2020 death of Breonna Taylor, who was shot to death by police during a raid at her home.

Louisville Mayor Greg Fischer, a Democrat, says good officers will welcome the probe as he does.

"We have much more work to do," said Fischer, adding "I strongly welcome the announcement made by Attorney General Merrick Garland."

Louisville Police Chief Erika Shields said the probe is necessary not just in Louisville, but in nearly every agency across the country.

Shields said if Louisville is "going to be one of the flagship departments for change, then bring it on."

The 26-year-old Taylor, an emergency medical technician who had been studying to become a nurse, was roused from her sleep by police who came through the door using a battering ram.

Her boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, fired once. A no-knock warrant was approved as part of a narcotics investigation. No drugs were found at her home.

snippet.description:
County officials in North Carolina say they are asking a judge to release bodycam footage of deputies killing a Black man.

"We continue to ask for patience as we follow the important process to proceed," said Pasquotank County Chief Deputy Daniel Fogg.

Authorities allowed the family of Andrew Brown Jr. to view a 20-second portion of the video.

An attorney for the family said that in the video, Brown did not appear to be a threat to officers as he backed his vehicle out and tried to drive away.  The video has not been made public.

A Black man killed by deputies in North Carolina was shot in the back of the head and had his hands on his car steering wheel when they opened fire, attorneys for his family said Monday after relatives viewed body camera footage.

"This tragic incident was quick and over in less than 30 seconds, and body cameras are shaky and sometimes hard to decipher. They only tell part of the story," Sheriff Tommy Wooten II said.

Brown's death last Wednesday led to nightly protests and demands for justice in the town of Elizabeth City.

snippet.description:
New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio called the Supreme Court's decision to hear an appeal to expand gun rights in the United States a "step in the wrong direction."

De Blasio made the comments to reporters on Monday during his daily briefing.

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a New York case over the right to carry a firearm in public for self-defense.

The case will be argued in the fall and marks the court's first foray into gun rights since Justice Amy Coney Barrett came on board in October, making a 6-3 conservative majority.

The justices said Monday that they'll review a lower-court ruling that upheld New York's restrictive gun permit law.

New York is among eight states that limit who has the right to carry a weapon in public.

snippet.description:
The U.S. announced Monday it would share its entire supply of AstraZeneca Plc‚Äôs Covid-19 vaccine with other countries and readied an aid package for India, as President Joe Biden pivots to ramp up U.S. pandemic assistance to the rest of the world.

The decision would make as many as 60 million vaccine doses available for export in coming months, if they clear a federal safety review. The plan represents a shift for Biden, who has hesitated to give vaccine doses and materials to other countries while focusing on ensuring Americans are vaccinated first.

‚ÄúGiven the strong portfolio of vaccines that the United States has already authorized and that is available in large quantities -- including two two-dose vaccines and one one-dose vaccine -- and given AstraZeneca is not authorized for use in the United States, we do not need to use AstraZeneca in our fight against Covid over the next few months,‚Äù White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki told reporters on Monday.

The announcement reflects growing pressure the U.S. has faced to share its vaccine supply with other countries, such as India, that have seen surges of Covid-19 infections or struggled to jump-start their vaccination drives. It also shows that the Biden administration is confident in its vaccine stockpile, especially after sites over the weekend were cleared to resume administering the Johnson & Johnson one-dose shot.

Subscribe to our YouTube channel: https://bit.ly/2TwO8Gm

snippet.description:
Britain said it is sending 600 pieces of medical equipment including ventilators to India to help the country in its fight against the coronavirus pandemic.

The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office said Sunday the first of nine plane-loads of kit would arrive in New Delhi on Tuesday.

The move follows discussion with the Indian government.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who had been due to visit India this week before the worsening situation there forced him to cancel, said Britain stands "side by side with India as a friend and partner" and would do whatever it could to support India through the crisis.

The assistance package includes 495 oxygen concentrators, 120 non-invasive ventilators and 20 manual ventilators from surplus U.K. stocks.

snippet.description:
Five stories to know for April 27: North Carolina shooting, Justice Department's probe into Breonna Taylor‚Äôs death, Republicans‚Äô drive to recall Gavin Newsom, India‚Äôs COVID deaths near 200,000 and fighting in Myanmar.

1. Attorneys for the family of Andrew Brown Jr., a Black man shot by sheriff's deputies in North Carolina during an attempted arrest last week, said body camera footage showed Brown had been ‚Äúexecuted".

2. The Justice Department launched a civil probe of the Louisville, Kentucky, police department whose officers last year fatally shot Breonna Taylor in a botched raid.

3. A Republican-led effort to recall California Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom has garnered enough valid signatures to make the ballot.

4. Vital medical supplies poured into India as hospitals starved of life-saving oxygen and beds turned away coronavirus patients, while a surge in infections pushed the death toll towards 200,000.

5. Ethnic minority Karen insurgents attacked a Myanmar army outpost near the Thai border in some of the most intense clashes since a military coup threw the country into crisis.

snippet.description:
Michael Kugelman of Wilson Center says the world has seen extent of suffering and death in India, Govt does not seem invested in meeting the needs of people

India is living through every nation‚Äôs nightmare. A breathless surge in active cases, a spike in daily deaths ‚Äì with question marks around official figures and a complete breakdown in medical infrastructure, from beds to oxygen. The scale and size of it has now taken us from a COVID second wave to a full-blown humanitarian crisis. How does the world look at these events and what is the urgent support India needs ? Mitali Mukherjee spoke with Michael Kugelman , Senior Associate for South Asia, Wilson Center. He said the world has seen the extent of suffering and death in India and it looks catastrophic and nightmarish. The Modi government has also come across as complacent and unwilling to recognize pandemic .

Mr Kugelman said there was a perception that the government had indulged in rampant politicization of the pandemic and a lot of soul searching was required on how it should work better for the country.

However he was confident the tragedy had not diminished India‚Äôs perception as an emerging leader and there was no question that there would be aid given from all quarters, including the U.S., U.K., France and even  established adversaries like China and Pakistan. Despite a delay in dispatching aid, relief and raw material clearances to India, he also believed the relationship with the U.S. remained strong as the world recognized the danger of India‚Äôs pandemic crisis tipping over into the region and worldwide.

snippet.description:
In a tour d‚Äôhorizon interview that comprehensively explains the likely impact of panic, as a result of the surging number of Covid cases, as well as the proliferating lockdowns on the economy, one of India‚Äôs most highly respected economists and the country‚Äôs former Chief Statistician says that he believes the fear and panic that is prevalent and growing as well as the uncertainty about lockdowns and how long they will last could make this year 2021 worse than last year. Prof. Pronab Sen also says that whilst everyone in the country was fooled into believing India had vanquished the virus it was, nonetheless, the government‚Äôs duty to make contingency plans in the event that wasn‚Äôt the case and its failure to do so is ‚Äúirresponsible‚Äù. As a result he says 11% GDP growth this year cannot be achieved. To do so would mean the economy has to grow beyond the GDP levels of 2019-20 and that, he says, won‚Äôt happen. This also means the government‚Äôs hopes of a V-shaped recovery will not be fulfilled. At best it could be an extended U. In fact, even earlier, it was more a K than a V. Finally, Prof. Sen said so far he hasn‚Äôt seen ‚Äúany worthwhile response‚Äù from the government. He said the government is behaving as if time is on its side but it‚Äôs not. If the government does not take immediate action ‚Äúthere can be serious damage‚Äù. 

In a 45-minute interview to Karan Thapar for The Wire Prof. Proneb Sen first spoke about the impact of the present climate of fear and panic on economic activity. ‚ÄúAny form of fear has a very substantial effect on the economic system. It changes people‚Äôs perceptions‚Äù. Prof. Sen said during the first Covid wave there was not much fear because the numbers were low and the death toll was low. Now, the numbers have gone up exponentially and deaths have gone up very sizeably and consequently the much greater level of fear will lead people to self-protect. That will dampen and restrict economic activity.

snippet.description:
In an interview to Shyam Bhatia, Jerome E. Kim, director general of the Seoul-based International Vaccine Institute, says India should ask the Chinese government to supply its surplus vaccines to help tide over its national shortage. There is a precedent from the Cold War of geopolitical rivals ‚Äì the United States and Soviet Union ‚Äì working together to fight against smallpox and polio.

snippet.description:
As India records some of the highest COVID-19 cases across the world, the country's medical infrastructure staggers to keep up. In the last 24 hours, there have been nearly 3 lakh new cases of COVID-19 and 2,771 deaths. 

In an interview to The Wire's Seraj Ali, Dr. Jitendra Padhariya, a pathologist with SRL Diagnostics in Gujarat, describes the medical crisis.
"We did nothing about the medical infrastructure," he says, recounting the developments in tackling the virus over the last year.

Dr. Padhariya also sheds light on the usage of Remdesivir for COVID-19 and the need for CT Scans along with RT-PCR tests.
Dr. Padhariya also says that we are no longer seeing milder cases of COVID-19 as often. 
He also remarks that the situation, in terms of lack of medical supplies, is so dire that even doctors who are on the frontline of the battle, won't be able to find a bed if they become infected.
"We wake up to see who's next," he says

He also remarks that the situation, in terms of lack of medical supplies, is so dire that even doctors who are on the frontline of the battle, won't be able to find a bed if they become infected.
"We wake up to see who's next," he says

Germany joins the UK, French in the South China Sea to face China head-on at disputes island

The German government and military officials recently revealed plans for the first German naval voyage to East Asia since 2002, in the wake of the country‚Äôs new Indo-Pacific guidelines. Amid increased French and British presence in the region ‚Äì and explicit invitations from Germany‚Äôs partners, Japan in particular ‚Äì this year‚Äôs trip is much less of a signal to Beijing than it is a message of support to Berlin‚Äôs allies.

From Sydney‚Äôs Bondi Beach, to Istanbul‚Äôs Bosphorus and the mountains of Caracas in Venezuela, the first supermoon of 2021 has been seen across the globe. A supermoon is a name given to a full moon that occurs when the moon is closest to the Earth. According at NASA, this year's super moon has been called a 'pink' super moon, as it appears in April and named after an American plant, pink phlox, that blooms in Spring

The husband of British aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe said they thought they 'could be close to the end when she got to the end of the sentence [...] It feels a little bit less like that now' following the news an Iranian court had sentenced her to a further year in jail. Richard Ratcliffe said the sentence, plus the one-year travel ban to follow it, is 'a long time'. Zaghari-Ratcliffe was arrested at Tehran airport in 2016 and accused of being a spy. She has been in jail and house arrest since then

Patients in New Delhi stood in long queues outside hospitals while others waited with oxygen masks in ambulances as India's new coronavirus infections hit a record high for a fifth consecutive day on Monday. Infections in the last 24 hours rose to 352,991, with overcrowded hospitals in Delhi and elsewhere turning away patients after running out of supplies of medical oxygen and beds

snippet.description:
As India battles a massive second wave of the coronavirus outbreak, many countries have offered support and expressed solidarity in the fight against the pandemic. Countries like Russia, Singapore,  France, Germany, the UK, the US, UAE several others have offered medical supplies, liquid oxygen, medical equipment and other medical aid as India grapples with a record-breaking surge in Covid cases. The European Union has activated its Civil Protection Mechanism to offer urgent oxygen and medical supplies to India. What does this help mean for India? Will this solidarity from friends and partner countries help India tide over this massive crisis is what 

Anchor/ producer: TEENA JHA

Guests:
Ashok Sajjanhar, Former Ambassador (top right 
Prof. Swaran Singh, Chairperson, CIPOD, JNU

snippet.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has ordered setting up of 551 oxygen plants inside government hospitals across the country. PM CARES Fund will provide financial aid in setting up these plants. PM Modi also ordered the concerned authorities to make these plants functional as soon as possible.
On April 23 Prime Minister Narendra Modi held a meeting with leading oxygen manufacturers across the country via video conferencing. PM Modi stressed on the need to maintain good co-ordination between the government and the oxygen producers.

GUESTS
1. DR. RAMAN R. GANGAKHEDKAR, Member, National Task Force for Covid-19
2. DR. DHRUVA CHAUDHRY, State Nodal Officer for Covid-19, Haryana

Anchor - Kriti Mishra
Producer- Saumya Nanda

snippet.title: Samaa News Headlines 5pm - Oxygen ki farhami itmenan bakhsh hai: Fawad Chaudhry | SAMAA TV

snippet.description:
#samaatvlive #pakistannewslive #news

CIE exams to be held in October/November now

Pakistan has cancelled all examinations till June 15, Federal Education Minister Shafqat Mahmood while addressing a press conference on Tuesday.

The O and A Level exams have been cancelled and pushed till October/November, he remarked, adding that no student will be promoted without exams this year.

We also discussed the concerns of students who cannot wait till September to take their exams as their year will be wasted. We are giving special permission to A2 students to take their exams and centres will be open for only them, Mehmood added. "Pakistan has around 20,000 A2 students."

He shared that centres should ensure that no more than 50 students are present at a time. The Pakistan Army will be deployed to ensure the SOP implementation.

Board exams were scheduled to be held in May and they have been postponed too, Mehmood added.

The federal minister said that they will ensure that Pakistan universities take in new admissions till January 2022 so that O/A Level students don't face placement issues.

These are difficult times and no decision is going to be easy, he said. "We have made this decision in collective spirit."

SOP violations
The government will discuss the violation of coronavirus SOPs at Cambridge examination centres across the country in a special meeting of the National Command and Operation Centre today (Tuesday), Federal Education Minister Shafqat Mahmood said earlier in the day.

A level students across Pakistan sat for their first exam on Monday, April 26. O level exams will, on the other hand, begin on May 10. The decision was taken by the federal government after a meeting with the international board.

On Tuesday, Mahmood tweeted there have been reports of poor SOP compliance outside examination centres. ‚ÄúPermission to hold exam was conditional on strict SOP observance.‚Äù

Ahead of the exams, the British Council announced SOPs for students, examination centres and the staff. This included social distancing, mandatory temperature checks, masks, use of gloves and hand sanitisers.

Students across Pakistan have been protesting against the exams. Some said their courses were not complete, while others raised concerns over the rising coronavirus cases.

They approached the high courts in Karachi, Islamabad, and Lahore but their petitions were dismissed.

Options available to students
On April 25, the Cambridge Assessment International Education released a statement in which it said that it has provided various options to Cambridge schools and students to support them through the pandemic.

In some syllabuses, candidates could take the component in a way that is easier to manage.
Schools could apply for exemptions where they feel candidates were not able to complete the syllabus.
Candidates can choose not to take a component but can still receive an overall syllabus grade.
Students can receive a grade when for any reason they miss some exams. Cambridge will give results to all students who have taken at least one component of the subject in the May/June 2021 exam series.
Students can defer to a future exam series with the same fee they paid for May/June 2021. The decision is theirs. They have till June 17 to make the decision.
Popular subjects in Pakistan will be offered in October/November 2021 exam series to facilitate students who decide to defer.
The British Council has announced the following precautionary measures for students, venue staff, and invigilators.

snippet.description:
NATO and partner air forces participated in Exercise Ramstein Alloy in the Baltic region on 20-21 April 2021. The NATO-led exercise involved German and Italian fighter jets from NATO‚Äôs Baltic Air Policing mission, as well as Polish fighter jets. Aircraft from NATO partners Finland and Sweden were also involved.

The aircrews practised real-world scenarios, including the procedures for air intercepts. On 20 April, Italian fighter jets based in Lithuania were scrambled for real, during the exercise, to intercept Russian fighters, bombers and surveillance aircraft over the Baltic Sea.

Ramstein Alloy occurs three times a year, once in each of the three Baltic countries. The main objective is to sharpen skills used in Baltic Air Policing efforts and enhance interoperability of air forces from NATO member and partner nations.

Footage includes shots of Lithuanian Air Force C27 Spartan, Finnish F/A-18 Hornets and German Eurofighter Typhoons in flight. Plus, shots of Latvian Air Force AN-2 Colt, Italian Air Force Eurofighter Typhoons in flight, shots of Italian Air Force during a scramble and soundbites from Colonel Viesturs Masulis, Latvian Air Force Commander.

snippet.description:
U.S. Marines with 1st Battalion, 10th Marine Regiment, 2d Marine Division, participate in Exercise Rolling Thunder 21.2 at Fort Bragg, NC., April 25, 2021.

This exercise is a 10th Marine Regiment-led live-fire artillery event that tests 10th Marines' abilities to operate in a simulated littoral environment against a peer threat in a dynamic and multi-domain scenario.

snippet.description:
U.S. Marines with Engineer Support Company, 9th Engineer Support Battalion, 3d Marine Logistics Group, and U.S. Navy Sailors with Naval Mobile Construction Battalion 4, post security in support of exercise Pacific Pioneer on Kin Blue training area, Okinawa, Japan.

Pacific Pioneer serves as 9th ESB's Marine Corps Combat Readiness Evaluation as well as an opportunity to demonstrate the ability to establish and sustain expeditionary advanced bases with survivable force protection, practice naval integration, and position long range precision fires and tactical logistics nodes across littoral regions in support of naval operations.

3d MLG, based out of Okinawa, Japan, is a forward deployed combat unit that serves as III MEF‚Äôs comprehensive logistics and combat service support backbone for operations throughout the Indo-Pacific area of responsibility.

Play War Thunder for FREE! Register using https://wt.link/DefenseUpdates and get a premium tank or aircraft or ship and thee days of premium account time.

The U.S. Army has begun deploying a new short-range air defense system.
The service announced unit forward deployed in Germany recently received the initial batch of  Mobile Short Range Air Defense, or M-SHORAD, systems.


The 5th Battalion, 4th Air Defense Artillery Regiment, based at Shipton Kaserne in Ansbach, Germany, is now equipped with M-SHORADs alongside its existing Humvee-based Avenger short-range air defense systems.

Viewers may note that M-SHORAD system is the first new short-range air defense system to be fielded by U.S. Army in decades
The deployment assumes importance since the threat from traditional fixed-wing aircraft, helicopters, missiles, and especially small drones have increased significantly.

In this video Defense Updates analyzes how the Stryker based M-SHORAD system will help U.S. Army to counter aerial threats?

snippet.description:
During the week between April 18 and 25, India reported 2.24 million new coronavirus cases, the highest number recorded by any country in a seven-day period. It also logged 16,257 deaths, almost double the 8,588 deaths recorded the previous week, according to Health Ministry data. India has been logging global daily records of over 300,000 cases for the last five days. The country saw 352,991 daily new infections and 2,812 COVID-related deaths in the past 24 hours. Altogether, 195,123 people have died while 17.3 million people have been infected with the virus in India. These numbers are staggering, but experts and epidemiological modelers believe that the real number of COVID fatalities could be much higher than the deaths recorded by health departments nationwide. "The distressing scenes of patients dying in ambulances and bodies burning on pyres outside crematoriums and even on pavements across cities and towns clearly show that the tragedy is far greater," Anoop Saraya, a private doctor, told DW.

Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

snippet.description:
The world's worst COVID 19 outbreak continues to spiral out of control in India. For the fifth straight day on Monday, the country recorded more than 300,000 cases, the highest global surges ever recorded. The increasing caseload has far outstripped available medical supplies, particularly oxygen. In the midst of the crisis in the country, social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter have emerged as life savers, literally. Indians are sharing pleas for help and information on availability of beds, oxygen and other medical supplies. But its also prompted criticism of the government's response to the crisis. Criticism that the government has decided to go after. Last week, following a 'legal request' from the government, Twitter blocked over 50 tweets in India, that were mostly critical of the government. According to a media report, the government felt these posts constituted 'social media misuse'. 

Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/user/deutschewelleenglish?sub_confirmation=1

#India #PandemicResponse #Twitter

localized.description:
The world's worst COVID 19 outbreak continues to spiral out of control in India. For the fifth straight day on Monday, the country recorded more than 300,000 cases, the highest global surges ever recorded. The increasing caseload has far outstripped available medical supplies, particularly oxygen. In the midst of the crisis in the country, social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter have emerged as life savers, literally. Indians are sharing pleas for help and information on availability of beds, oxygen and other medical supplies. But its also prompted criticism of the government's response to the crisis. Criticism that the government has decided to go after. Last week, following a 'legal request' from the government, Twitter blocked over 50 tweets in India, that were mostly critical of the government. According to a media report, the government felt these posts constituted 'social media misuse'.

snippet.description:
There's a helpful concept we use to help understand what distance from a given star you might expect to find planets with liquid water on their surface ‚Äì liquid water being essential for life as we know it. It's called the habitable zone. Every star has a habitable zone, but where that zone lies is different for stars of different sizes and brightness. 

Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

snippet.description:
Family members of a deceased patient allegedly indulged in violence and vandalism at an Apollo hospital facility in Delhi on April 27. Hospital officials said that the patient was brought in the early hours of the morning. Due to paucity of beds, the family was asked to take her to another hospital. However, the patient died at 8 am, following which the relatives allegedly attacked hospital staff and destroyed property. Watch the full video for more.

snippet.description:
Maharashtra Health Minister Rajesh Tope said the availability of anti-COVID-19 vaccines is still a challenge and the state needs a week's quota delivered at one time in order to vaccinate a maximum number of people. The Centre has relaxed its COVID-19 vaccination strategy in the third phase under which the country's large 18-plus population will get inoculated from May 1. He said Maharashtra alone needs 12 crore vaccine vials to inoculate the population of 5.71 crores in the age group of 18 to 44. He said Maharashtra alone needs 12 crore vaccine vials to inoculate the population of 5.71 crores in the age group of 18 to 44. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
As India's Covid-19 crisis continues, more videos of people desperately seeking help surfaced. People reportedly begged for oxygen outside a hospital in Haryana's Rewari. Meanwhile, the Chief Minister commented on the situation. He said that a controversy shouldn't be raised on the issue of deaths data. Watch the full video for more.

snippet.description:
The Delhi High Court Tuesday said the AAP government's entire system has failed as black marketing of oxygen cylinders and crucial medicines for treating COVID-19 patients is going on. A bench of Justices Vipin Sanghi and Rekha Palli observed it was not the time to become vultures. ‚ÄúAre you aware of black marketing. Is it a good human gesture?‚Äù, the bench said to oxygen refillers. The bench further said this is a mess that the state government has been unable to resolve. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description: The world now watches in horror as India struggles to cope with the second wave of the corona virus in India. The country is seeing a record number of new cases and people dying, many times due to oxygen scarcity. The US has promised help with stocks of vaccines or its raw materials but what more can be done. We speak to Dr Ashish Jha, dean at Brown University

snippet.description:
A man was seen shooting at his pregnant wife in Delhi‚Äôs Nizamuddin area on Tuesday. The incident was caught on CCTV camera where the man, identified as Waseem, took several aims at his wife. The woman, Saina, was killed and her aide Shahdat, who tried to intervene, was also shot at by Waseem. Video of the dramatic incident was released. Saina was released from jail on bail three days ago as she was eight months pregnant with twins. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description:
A couple in Madhya Pradesh tied the knot in a ceremony where the bride and groom were both donning PPE kits. The groom had tested positive on 19th of April, 2021 and both were seen performing all rituals with their PPE kits. Some family members and policemen were also present at the ceremony. Gatherings for social and religious purposes have been restricted in Madhya Pradesh and in several states across India, to slow the spread of Covid. The state has limited the number of people at weddings to 50. Watch the full video for all the details.

snippet.description:
The last 'shahi snan' at the Kumbh Mela in Haridwar on Tuesday was a subdued affair with seers keeping the ritual symbolic in view of a nationwide surge in COVID-19 cases. Prime Minister Narendra Modi on April 17 had appealed to sadhus to observe the remaining duration of the Kumbh only in a "symbolic" manner. Following this different 'akhadas' (sects) had agreed to keep their participation symbolic. Crowds at the ghats of the Ganga started thinning down drastically since last week after the key 'akhadas' of seers began pulling out of the Maha Kumbh, one of the largest religious gatherings in the world, citing the spike in coronavirus case numbers. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description: With Delhi facing a crippling shortage of life-saving oxygen, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday said his government will import 18 cryogenic tankers from Thailand and 21 ready-to-use oxygen plants from France. In the next month, the Delhi government will set up 44 oxygen plants at various hospitals, including 21 that will be imported from France. The Centre will install eight oxygen plants by April 30, Kejriwal said during an online briefing. The Delhi government has urged the Centre to provide Indian Air Force aircraft for bringing the oxygen tankers from Bangkok. The tankers will start arriving in Delhi on Wednesday, he added. Watch the full video for more details.

snippet.description: A day after the Madras High Court made scathing observations against the election commission, the poll panel has now banned all victory processions on the day of & even after counting of votes on May 2, 2021. The election commission also said that not more than two persons shall be allowed to accompany the winning candidate while they receive the certificate of election from the Returning Officer. This comes a day after the Madras High Court rapped the poll panel for allowing political rallies during the pandemic and not enforcing Covid protocols strictly. So is the election commission directive a late attempt at making amends? Will political parties and their workers adhere to the directives of the poll panel. Watch the latest edition of In Focus for the latest.

snippet.description:
Opposition politicians in Georgia are set to return to Parliament after a six-month boycott since elections in October the opposition claimed were marred by violations.  
EU diplomats helped broker a deal last week to end the political deadlock that has simmered for nearly two years since demonstrations broke out in June 2019.
Georgians are still demanding justice for the people injured during the protests.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Robin Forestier-Walker reports from Tbilisi, Georgia.

snippet.description:
Saudi Arabia has suspended the import of fruit and vegetables from Lebanon; it says shipments are being used for drug smuggling after millions of pills were found in boxes of pomegranates.
Lebanon exports 400,000 tonnes of agricultural produce every year, one-fourth to Saudi Arabia and the wider Gulf region. The suspension means millions of dollars in losses for a country facing a deep economic and financial crisis.
The head of the farmer‚Äôs association in the Bekaa Valley says investigations showed the pomegranates came from Syria, not Lebanon.
Lebanon‚Äôs leaders ordered the security services to crack down on drug smuggling and those behind it, but many feel these promises from a weak state will not change anything.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut, Lebanon.

snippet.description:
A decade after a landmark land restitution law passed in Colombia, returning families displaced by confrontations between FARC rebels and paramilitary groups to their properties remains an uphill battle. 
Just a fraction of the land has been assigned and few projects have been established to guarantee returning families a livelihood in a place scarred by conflict. 
Those families who have returned - and are trying to make a new living by planting legal crops instead of coca - are worried that the slow pace of reparations will allow violence to rack the region again.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Alessandro Rampietti reports from Valle del Guamez, Colombia.

snippet.description:
Authorities in Mexico are urging people to conserve water as a prolonged drought over 85 percent of the country depletes reservoirs and lakes.
Scientists are saying the climate crisis is altering rain patterns which has also contributed to severe forest fires.
Mexico City's mayor says the drought is the worst in 30 years. 

Al Jazeera's Manuel Rapalo reports from Mexico City, Mexico.

Protests over the police killing of Andrew Brown Junior continue in the US state of North Carolina where he was fatally shot by sheriff‚Äôs deputies last week, as Brown‚Äôs family viewed bodycam footage of the incident.
Brown, a Black man, was killed on April 21 in Elizabeth City, North Carolina, by police serving a drug-related arrest warrant, sparking days of protest. 
His relatives and their attorneys say Brown posed no threat to officers as he tried to leave the scene in his vehicle.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Rob Reynolds reports.

snippet.description:
Human Rights Watch is accusing Israel of the crimes against humanity of apartheid and persecution against Palestinians in some areas. 
In a report published on Tuesday, the rights group says the discriminatory policies exist both in the Occupied Palestinian Territories and within Israel itself. 
This is the second high profile report this year to accuse Israel of practising apartheid. In January, Israeli rights group B‚ÄôTselem said the Israeli government was enacting Jewish supremacist policies.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Harry Fawcett reports from Occupied East Jerusalem.

snippet.description:
An Iranian Revolutionary court has sentenced a British-Iranian woman, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, to a one-year jail term after she was found guilty of spreading propaganda.
The latest conviction dates back to Zaghari-Ratcliffe allegedly taking part in a protest in front of the Iranian embassy in London 12 years ago. 
Zaghari-Ratcliffe had just finished serving a five-year sentence on separate charges for plotting against Iran's government.
Her family says she is being used as a bargaining chip and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has condemned Iran's move.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs Paul Brennan reports from London, UK.

snippet.description:
Hundreds of thousands of fresh COVID-19 cases in India are overwhelming hospitals, as state and local authorities re-impose restrictions to check the country‚Äôs most serious outbreak yet of coronavirus infections.

The number of deaths is increasing day-on-day. More than 189,000 people across the country have now died due to COVID-19. 

But there is little sign that national, state and local authorities are succeeding in slowing a devastating second coronavirus wave that people say is being underestimated. Test kits are in short supply and bureaucratic hurdles are frustrating people‚Äôs efforts to get prompt medical attention. Hospitals across India are now running out of beds, oxygen, and medicines. 

Mixed government messaging on how to tackle the rising tide of cases and deaths is exacerbating the crisis. Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has faced widespread criticism on social media by citizens and opposition politicians, on April 20 said the latest wave of infections ‚Äúhas come like a storm‚Äù, but maintains that lockdown measures should only be used by states as ‚Äúthe last resort‚Äù. 

As India faces the challenges of flattening the curve while trying to monitor new variants and revive a vaccination drive that has lagged in recent weeks, we‚Äôll ask how the country can get control over the resurgence of COVID-19.

Join the conversation:

snippet.description:
Serum Institute of India, producer of Covishield, has fixed the price per dose for supply to Central government at Rs 150, to state governments at Rs 400 and to private hospitals at Rs 600.


Bharat Biotech, the producer of Covaxin, has fixed an entirely different range of prices i.e. price per dose to Central government Rs 150, to state governments at Rs 600 and to private hospitals Rs 1,200.

The total cases till now are 1,76,36,307 and recoveries are 1,45,56,209 while death toll has gone up to 1,97,894.
