snippet.description:
Two million saxaul seedlings planted on Aral seabed. Qazaq TV News

#saxaulseedlings #Aral #AralSea #saxaul #seedlings

Every year the wind blows up to 100 million tonnes of salt and dust from the seabed.

By 2025, 213,000 hectares of saxaul will be planted on the dried bottom of the Aral Sea. According to the Kazakh Ministry of Ecology, Geology and Natural Resources, nearly two million tree seedlings have been planted to date. Every year the wind blows up to 100 million tonnes of salt and dust from the seabed. Saxaul can reduce this negative effect. One tree can hold up to four tonnes of sand. A regional project aimed at promoting the environmentally sustainable development of the Aral Sea Region was launched this year. It is funded by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development. The project is being implemented until 2024 in Karakalpakstan and Khorezm region of Uzbekistan, as well as Kazakhstan‚Äôs Kyzylorda and Mangystau regions.

snippet.description:
Two artists from Kazakhstan present their works in Nur-Sultan. Qazaq TV News

#artists #Kazakhstan #FreedomofconsciousnessoftheGreatSteppe #exhibition #NurSultan
  
The joint exhibition presents 66 works.

An exhibition entitled ‚ÄúFreedom of consciousness of the Great Steppe‚Äù dedicated to the 30th anniversary of Kazakhstan‚Äôs Independence opened in Nur-Sultan. It was organized by an artist of an international level Marzhan Abildina. The exposition also displays paintings of her student Eva Verchenko. The joint exhibition presents 66 works. The paintings tell about the vastness of the Kazakh land and the beauty of its nature.

‚ÄúWe decided to hold and organize this exhibition as a gift for residents and visitors of the capital on the eve of the holiday. She studied at an art school for six years, creating new projects every year. We selected 12 paintings most suitable for the theme of the nature of Kazakhstan to express our love and respect for our land, so that children see that it is possible to embody the love for their homeland through art. 44 works are made by me. They were displayed at exhibitions in Germany, France, South Korea. I work more in Kazakhstan during the pandemic, making new works. I made several paintings in January and February and decided to present them as well,‚Äù said an artist and organizer Marzhan Abildina.

The festive exhibition will last until the end of May. According to the organizers, it will be available online due to quarantine measures.

localized.description:
Two artists from Kazakhstan present their works in Nur-Sultan. Qazaq TV News

#artists #Kazakhstan #FreedomofconsciousnessoftheGreatSteppe #exhibition #NurSultan
  
The joint exhibition presents 66 works.

An exhibition entitled ‚ÄúFreedom of consciousness of the Great Steppe‚Äù dedicated to the 30th anniversary of Kazakhstan‚Äôs Independence opened in Nur-Sultan. It was organized by an artist of an international level Marzhan Abildina. The exposition also displays paintings of her student Eva Verchenko. The joint exhibition presents 66 works. The paintings tell about the vastness of the Kazakh land and the beauty of its nature.

‚ÄúWe decided to hold and organize this exhibition as a gift for residents and visitors of the capital on the eve of the holiday. She studied at an art school for six years, creating new projects every year. We selected 12 paintings most suitable for the theme of the nature of Kazakhstan to express our love and respect for our land, so that children see that it is possible to embody the love for their homeland through art. 44 works are made by me. They were displayed at exhibitions in Germany, France, South Korea. I work more in Kazakhstan during the pandemic, making new works. I made several paintings in January and February and decided to present them as well,‚Äù said an artist and organizer Marzhan Abildina.

The festive exhibition will last until the end of May. According to the organizers, it will be available online due to quarantine measures.

snippet.description:
‚ÄúAshyq‚Äù project to cover all regions of Kazakhstan. Qazaq TV News 

#Ashyq #project #Kazakhstan #Atameken #PCRtesting #entrepreneurs

To use the app, you just need to download it and enter the individual identification number. 

The number of users of the Ashyq project in Kazakhstan reached 300,000. Despite the epidemiological situation, it will cover all regions from today, announced Deputy Director of Health Service Department at the ‚ÄúAtameken‚Äù National Chamber of Entrepreneurs, Assel Muratkhanova.

‚ÄúIf you passed PCR testing and the result is negative, then you will have a ‚Äúgreen‚Äù status for 72 hours. After 72 hours, or if you have not passed PCR testing at all, your status will be ‚Äúblue‚Äù. If you tested positive, the status will be ‚Äúred‚Äù for two weeks. It does not matter if you passed PCR testing, recovered or not, the status will remain the same for two weeks. All contacted people will have a ‚Äúyellow‚Äù status,‚Äù she said.

To use the app, you just need to download it and enter the individual identification number. Then you will have the opportunity to freely visit any institution which supports the Ashyq project.

‚ÄúFirst, it makes it possible for entrepreneurs to work and run their business. This is particularly relevant for bowling, billiard rooms, computer clubs, karaoke, which are closed to date. Plus, of course, it is a matter of safety. We prevent the spread of the disease this way,‚Äù Muratkhanova added.

The project is developed by Kazakh IT experts together with Kazakh Ministry of Digital Development, Innovation and Aerospace Industry. Its main goal is to help entrepreneurs. According to experts, many countries have an analogue of the Ashyq project. Therefore, they are confident that there will be no difficulties in the future.

Australia suspended all direct passenger flights from India due to a spike in Covid-19 cases. The decision was taken during a meeting of the cabinet‚Äôs National Security Committee. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the suspension would be in force till at least 15 May.

#ArvindKejriwal #Delhi #Covid
Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal Tuesday said his government has decided to import 18 oxygen tankers from Bangkok and 21 ready-to-use oxygen plants from France to address the shortage amid rising Covid cases. "Talks are on, I'm very hopeful that talks will be successful," Kejriwal added.

snippet.description:
On the debate over data of Covid deaths, Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar told the media: "Iss sankat mein humko data ke saath nahi khelna hai. We should focus on seeing how people can recover." He said there is no point in a debate over the number of deaths. "The dead won't resurrect with furore over it," he added

snippet.description:
#CovidReturns #LockdownMP #CovidPandemicInIndia
Roughly 100 km away from Indore, Maheshwar, the 'weaving capital' of the state, wears a deserted look, bereft of any people or activity. The clickety-clack of the looms had just begun to fill the air in this sari-weaving town after nearly nine months of despair and desolation. But as the second wave of coronavirus infections hit India, orders dried up again. ThePrint‚Äôs Revathi Krishnan and Taran Deol report from the ground.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://theprint.in/india/maheshwar-saree-looms-go-silent-again-just-as-they-were-recovering-from-2020/645623/?amp#click=https://t.co/sYZ489wU3L

snippet.description:
#MadhyaPradesh #Ratlam
It was a different wedding in Ratlam, Madhya Pradesh, on 26 April. The couple was in PPE suits during the ceremony as the groom had tested positive for Covid-19 on 19 April. The wedding took place at a marriage hall in Ratlam with the permission of the local administration. Family members attended the ceremony in the presence of police personnel.

snippet.description:
Six new cases of coronavirus have been recorded in Fiji. the capital Suva has entered a 14-day lockdown after an outbreak from a quarantine centre spread to the city. The towns of Nadi and Lautoka went into lockdown earlier in the month, when a soldier who worked at the centre contracted the virus and spread it to a hotel worker. Journalist Lice Movono says the Fiji may have been too complacent with its quarantine protocols.

Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  

Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-04-26/fiji-suva-goes-into-covid-lockdown/100095712 

ABC News provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad, including the latest coronavirus pandemic updates. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation.

snippet.description:

Several Australian cricketers are still in India playing in the Indian Premier League (IPL) ‚Äî which is scheduled to finish on May 31 ‚Äî including Steve Smith, Pat Cummins and David Warner.

Andrew Tye, Adam Zampa and Kane Richardson have cut short their IPL seasons and headed home.

He said special arrangements would not be made for cricketers when they wanted to return to Australia.

Queensland's Health Minister has called on the federal government to help free up hospital beds, as the state's leading medical association warns the public heath system is at "crisis point".

Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said almost 600 hospital beds could be freed up across the state "if the Commonwealth was to step in today", by providing more aged care and disability packages.

Ms D'Ath's comments came after the Australian Medical Association Queensland (AMAQ) warned the state's public hospitals were struggling to cope with clogged emergency departments, too few beds, and burnt-out staff.

snippet.description:
Dozens of coronavirus victims were cremated at a site in New Delhi, Monday, April 26, as cases continue to surge in India. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî 
READ MORE: India reported 352,991 new confirmed cases of COVID-19 on Monday, the fifth consecutive day of more than 300,000 coronavirus infections in the South Asian nation as it deals with a catastrophic second wave of the pandemic.    

The country‚Äôs health care system has collapsed in the wave, with hospitals filled beyond capacity and unable to care for any new patients and a shortage of oxygen canisters so dire that some COVID patients are literally gasping for air. 

India also posted 2,812 deaths Monday, another record one-day number, as crematories have been busy night and day setting fire to the dead.  The capital New Delhi has extended a lockdown that was set to expire on Monday for another week.   

The second wave has been blamed on the spread of more contagious variants of the virus, plus the easing of restrictions on large crowds when the outbreak appeared to be under control earlier this year. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

snippet.description:
The disaster at Chernobyl is still considered one of the worst nuclear accidents in history. It happened on April 26, 1986. Thirty-five years later, a group of survivors returns to the ghost city of Pripyat in northern Ukraine.

A senior engineer who worked building the reactor, a maternity doctor from a local hospital, and an 11-year-old girl evacuated from Pripyat survived, as did a firefighter who served in Reactor Block 4 and an army officer who was in charge of removing radioactive debris from the reactor's roof. This documentary follows them as they return to their deserted homes for the first time. Their memories come together like pieces of a puzzle that depicts the fateful events of 1986. Firefighters and soldiers who became known as "liquidators" risked their lives to stabilize the site and prevent even greater radioactive contamination of Europe and the world. Only a few survived the mission. This emotional documentary recounts a major historical drama in small, intimate stories, while using never before seen archive material that the people of Pripyat had hidden in their homes.

#Chernobyl #documentary #dwdocumentary

localized.description:
The disaster at Chernobyl is still considered one of the worst nuclear accidents in history. It happened on April 26, 1986. Thirty-five years later, a group of survivors returns to the ghost city of Pripyat in northern Ukraine.

A senior engineer who worked building the reactor, a maternity doctor from a local hospital, and an 11-year-old girl evacuated from Pripyat survived, as did a firefighter who served in Reactor Block 4 and an army officer who was in charge of removing radioactive debris from the reactor's roof. This documentary follows them as they return to their deserted homes for the first time. Their memories come together like pieces of a puzzle that depicts the fateful events of 1986. Firefighters and soldiers who became known as "liquidators" risked their lives to stabilize the site and prevent even greater radioactive contamination of Europe and the world. Only a few survived the mission. This emotional documentary recounts a major historical drama in small, intimate stories, while using never before seen archive material that the people of Pripyat had hidden in their homes.

#Chernobyl #documentary #dwdocumentary

FOX News Channel (FNC) is a 24-hour all-encompassing news service delivering breaking news as well as political and business news. The number one network in cable, FNC has been the most-watched television news channel for 18 consecutive years. According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

The Election Commission of India (ECI) has banned all victory processions on or after the counting of votes for the assembly elections in five states that will be declared on May 2. In its detailed order, Election Commission has said not more than two people will be allowed to accompany the winning candidate to receive their victory certificate for the May 2 election result.
The Election Commission ban on victory processions comes as the country witnesses a severe second wave of Covid-19 that has been claiming over 2,000 lives on a daily basis for the past several days.

snippet.description:
A parallel world of human trafficking exists in plain sight all around us, we just can‚Äôt see it. Modern slaves from Vietnam are working in nail bars, in restaurants and in brothels and cannabis farms across the UK. Guardian journalist Annie Kelly worked closely with lawyer and director at Duncan Lewis Ahmed Aydeed to tell the story of Minh and fight for his freedom. 

Minh was just 16 when he was raped and trafficked from Vietnam to the UK. He was forced to grow cannabis alone in a house in Derbyshire, where the plants were more valuable than his life. When the police arrived to raid the property, he was criminalised instead of protected. 

Ahmed fought tirelessly for Minh‚Äôs freedom, and after 12 legal challenges his conviction was overturned and he was granted the right to remain in the UK. This is his story.
